The Request for Change of Instruction Model may be used again at a later date if you need to change your child's choice.

March 25, 2020

Dear Parents, Guardians, and Caregivers,
I am writing to share my appreciation for the feedback we received from parents through our most recent Thoughtexchange, which closed yesterday. Class III Officers

Two Additional Class III Special Law Enforcement Officers were approved at the January 23rd meeting of the Board of Education. These officers will serve at the elementary schools on a rotating basis beginning in February 2020.

Superintendent, Dr. Mark Toback, commented, “We are thrilled that Class III Law Enforcement Officers Brent Cannon and John Costabile will be assigned to our elementary schools. Our newest Class III officers are retired from the Wayne Police Department, and each has a long and distinguished record of service to this community. The addition of Class III officers at each of our middle schools is widely recognized as a great boost to our safety and security initiatives. We look forward to seeing a similar benefit at each of our elementary schools.”

GWMS Faculty Are Talking About "Educated: A Memoir"

Tara Westover, author of Educated, a New York Times Top Ten Book of 2018, wrote “I don’t think education is so much about making a living, it’s about making a person". Westover's educational philosophy appealed to the teachers of George Washington Middle School to the extent that they planned and participated in a two-month long dialogue about this important book.

Members of the GWMS “Don’t Call it a Book Club” Book Club met early Friday mornings throughout February and March. By sharing personal experiences and their reactions to Educated, teachers shared ideas about what education is, and what it offers: the perspective to see one’s life through new eyes and the willingness to change it.

Only the bell signaling the start of the school day interrupted the rich discourse that could be overheard as students entered the building. The group is currently researching book titles for their next book chat which will resume in May.

Dear Parents and Guardians,

This morning, we received a number of calls from parents regarding whether or not the district will have an early dismissal due to the anticipated bad weather. At this time, the weather forecast calls for some snow followed by rain. Based on this forecast, an early dismissal would mean we would be placing students and employees on the road when the weather conditions will probably be the most hazardous. At our regular dismissal time, the forecast calls for warmer temperatures and rain. Safety is our first priority and we will have a regular dismissal for today. At your discretion, if you choose to pick up your child before the regular close of the school day, we will accommodate your request through our normal sign-out procedures.

Regards,

Mark Toback, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools
Wayne Township Public Schools

Dear Parents, Guardians and Students: The end of January usually marks a time when we receive a flood of correspondence from parents regarding their desire to not have their children participate in the New Jersey Department of Education standardized testing program. With the 2015 transition to a computer-based testing program (PARCC) and the resulting skepticism over the use and sharing of student data, the widespread unpopularity of the Common Core State Standards and other state-mandated reforms, and a host of other problems too numerous to list, parents and students had many reasons to be concerned.

This is a free preschool program where high school students help preschoolers learn Pre-Kindergarten skills such as: alphabet, animals, colors, holidays, manners, math, numbers, seasons, shapes, and science.

The program can accommodate up to ten children.

Located in room 132 of Wayne Valley High School.

The program follows Wayne Township Public School District's calendar. Preschool will be cancelled on snow days, delayed openings, and early dismissals.

Requirements:
- Must be fully potty trained
- Must be 3-5 years old (not yet attending Kindergarten)
- Must be a Wayne Resident (driver’s licenses must reflect residency)
- Must provide a copy of your child’s immunization records

Start Date: October 9, 2018

Days: Tuesdays and Thursdays (Children must be able to attend both days) until the first week in June.

Drop off: 11:20 AM
Pick up: 1:20 PM

Please contact lfolenta@wayneschools.com for more information

It is with great excitement that I write to you today to welcome you back to school. Now in my fifth year as Superintendent of Schools, it remains a pleasure to serve Wayne Township and continue to push forward with our shared goal of providing an exceptional educational system. Together, We CAN End Childhood Poverty in Our Community!

Prior to wrapping up the school year Ready, Set, Serve!, GW’s Service Learning Club, sponsored a food drive to assist local food pantries as they strive to provide meals for families in need during the summer months. Sadly, most food pantries are depleted of the most basic and essential items at this time of year and schools and other organizations are unavailable to contribute during the summer. Seeing this as a desperate need right here in our neighborhoods, members of Ready, Set, Serve! rallied around the cause and together with the entire George Washington Middle School community collected close to 1,000 donations of much needed items such as tuna, peanut butter, jelly, pasta, canned tomato sauce, canned fruits and vegetables. St. Mary’s food pantry in Pompton Lakes was so very grateful for the overwhelming generosity of GWMS's faculty and students. As a community committed to serving others, we were once again reminded that together we CAN (and did!) make a difference in the lives of those in need!

Ryerson Elementary School Introduces Girls on the Run!

Ryerson Elementary School girls are on the RUN! Girls on the Run is a transformational, physical activity based, positive youth development program for girls in 3rd-5th grade. Girls learn life skills through dynamic interactive lessons and running games. The program culminated with the girls being physically and emotionally prepared to complete a celebratory 5k running event on May 12. In their first season participating in the program, 9 girls from 3rd, 4th and 5th grade, practiced twice a week after school to run their first 5K!

George Washington Middle School Student Council Takes Home Award

George Washington Middle School students attended the New Jersey Association of Student Councils Awards Ceremony held at Six Flags Great Adventure on May 30th. The Student Council was once again recognized for their outstanding fundraising efforts and took home the Community Smile Award. The students worked tirelessly and performed many hours of service in order to achieve this honor. The GW community is so proud of them!
